messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "lancezant" <lancezant@...> wrote:
>
> Folks,
>
> I've been watching this thread for a while, but missed the
beginning.
> Has anyone mentioned JUnit4's ability to mark tests @ignore?
That's
> a potentially huge business plus.

...

> Lance Zant


MDT - Agreed! (Lance, appreciate your point.) @Ignore is an
effective and appropriate use of declarative programming. One could
also use a properties file (descriptor document) as an alternative
declarative technique.

[In fact, TestUtil went down this path by excluding classes and
methods using a descriptor document until Mark Levison suggested
using a JavaDoc tag (@excludeClass etc.) instead.]

So if annotations are an effective style of declarative programming,
what's the problem?

1) There are contexts where both an OOP solution and a declarative
solution is effective. I happen to prefer an OOP solution as a
first choice. ("test" vs "@Test") I'm perfectly willing to accept
that others prefer a declarative solution (over an OOP solution) as
a matter of style.

2) What I'm not prepared to accept, is an assertion that
declarative programming is "better" (when there are two workable
choices) by virtue of its existence. In the case of @Ignore - no
question about it (in my mind) - that is a problem begging for a
declarative solution. In the case of "test" - there are real-world
tradeoffs between going down a declarative path vs. an OOP path.


In other words:

The basis for promoting declarative annotations when an OOP solution
exists can not be ---> annotations don't require (or, take advantage
of) inheritance so they are automatically better in all contexts!

Shouldn't a balanced declarative vs. OOP discussion include what one
gives up by abandoning inheritance in three contexts:

- Team context
- Corporate context
- Platform context

And two dimensions:

- In-container testing
- Outside-the-container testing


_Marvin
